IR (KBr): 2122(vs) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">SCN</ce:inf>); 1642(w), 1611(w), 1580(w), 1531(m) and 1516(m) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">Me-Im</ce:inf>) and ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:inf loc="post">Me-Im</ce:inf>).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">(<ce:bold>2)</ce:bold> Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>

IR Br): 3096(m) ν (OH); 2129(vs) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">SCN</ce:inf>); 1620(m), 1536w) and 1524(w) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">tp</ce:inf>) and ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:inf loc="post">tp</ce:inf>).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">(<ce:bold>3)</ce:bold> [Mn(bopy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Hg(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>: Yield 80%. IR (KBr): 2133(vs) and 2144(vs) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">SCN</ce:inf>); 1639(s) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:inf loc="post">bopy</ce:inf>) and 1593(m) and 1568(w) ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">bopy</ce:inf>) and ν (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:inf loc="post">bopy</ce:inf>).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Crystal structures determination and refinement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The X-ray intensity data of <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were collected on a Gemini A Ultra diffractometer equipped with Atlas CCD detector and graphite monochromated Mo<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the Patterson method and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as ‘cycling’ on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (non-methyl) and 1.5 (methyl) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. <ce:small-caps>shelxs97</ce:small-caps> and <ce:small-caps>shelxs97</ce:small-caps>
 programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. The one of the phenyl rings of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is statically disordered over two sites with about 1:1 participation of domains.</ce:para>
clean_text:
(1) [Mn(Me-Im)2Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 85%. IR (KBr): 2122(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1642(w), 1611(w), 1580(w), 1531(m) and 1516(m) ν (CNMe-Im) and ν (CCMe-Im).

(2) Mn(tp)(MeOH)Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 75%. IR Br): 3096(m) ν (OH); 2129(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1620(m), 1536w) and 1524(w) ν (CNtp) and ν (CCtp).

(3) [Mn(bopy)2Hg(SCN)4] n : Yield 80%. IR (KBr): 2133(vs) and 2144(vs) ν (CNSCN); 1639(s) ν (CObopy) and 1593(m) and 1568(w) ν (CNbopy) and ν (CCbopy).

Crystal structures determination and refinement

The X-ray intensity data of 1-3 were collected on a Gemini A Ultra diffractometer equipped with Atlas CCD detector and graphite monochromated MoK α radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. Details concerning crystal data and refinement are given in  . Lorentz, polarization and empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm  were applied. The structures were solved by the Patterson method and subsequently completed by the difference Fourier recycling. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using full-matrix, least-squares technique. The hydrogen atoms were treated as ‘cycling' on their parent carbon atoms and assigned isotropic temperature factors equal 1.2 (non-methyl) and 1.5 (methyl) times the value of equivalent temperature factor of the parent atom. The methyl groups were allowed to rotate about their local threefold axis. shelxs97 and shelxs97  programs were used for all the calculations. Atomic scattering factors were those incorporated in the computer programs. The one of the phenyl rings of 3 is statically disordered over two sites with about 1:1 participation of domains.
